Posts.Content: I retired, after 41 years at the Postal Service, on Jan 2, 2015 and started chemo 4 days later! Next week will be my last (15th) Herceptin infusion. I've had a lumpectomy, 6 rounds of chemo and 35 days of radiation. Now I will be on Anastrozole for 5 years. The side effects I experienced are tinnitus and neuropathy on the bottom of my feet. My heart doesn't seem to be as strong as it used to be either! But hey, after all, I am 69 years old. Nothing is as it used to be! During this last year I have lost, in addition to my hair, 30 pounds. Something I've been trying to do for 25 years. But I wouldn't recommend chemo as a diet! The steroids I received during chemo help with my arthritis. But I wouldn't recommend it for that either! I became more and more concerned when I found it hard to find someone with Her2+/neu cancer. Nowhere did I see that it was rare. I concluded that people are not to be found because they don't survive! Pretty upsetting - but now I attribute my silly deduction to "chemo brain". Not thinking clearly! We can and DO survive! So, to keep my cancer at bay... I've changed my diet, thanks to foodforbreastcancer.com " target="_blank" rel="nofollow">www.foodforbreastcancer.com and go to a cancer support group at a nearby hospital/fitness center, and joined the Livestrong program at the YMCA. It's free and helps breast cancer survivors regain their strength, stamina and balance. I was alway very physically active but the chemo knocked me for a loop 10 out of the 21 day cycles. And it progressively got longer each cycle. The last chemo session seemed to take a couple of months before I was strong enough to leave the house. I would love to hear what women do/not do to stay cancer free. According to foodforbreastcancer.com we (her2+) need a different diet than other cancer survivors. Staying clear of foods with phytoestrogens like soy. I (may be mistakenly) believe ever word I read there because my oncologist tells me absolutely nothing! I think I should be searching for a new oncologist online too! I hope everyone here is doing well and will respond telling me of their methods of keeping well!
Posts.Title: HER2/Neu protein positive breast cancer
